ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
ygData.msgSnippet: I m not sure ... I don t think i understand the issues you mention. * I dont know what you mean by navigate|embed means. If i have an HTTP link to a resource

X-Yahoo-Profile: peter_e_williams

I'm not sure

On Mon, Jan 9, 2012 at 12:08 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@yahoo.=
com> wrote:
> However, I've not yet been able to design an RDF media type t=
hat
> _also_ expresses protocol-level semantics (i.e. navigate|embed,
> pro=
tocol method, body|uri variables, idempotency, etc.) that a wide
> range of=
 clients can consume (even those not "interested in" the
> protocol semanti=
cs available in the RDF media type).

I don't think i understand the issues=
 you mention.

 * I dont know what you mean by "navigate|embed" means. If i=
 have an
HTTP link to a resource then i can, by virtue of the uniform
inter=
face, try to navigate to that url. If the resource does not
support GET it =
will respond with 405. Embedding is a very different
issue that seem deeply=
 related to the media type. For example it is
trivial with RDF-ish media ty=
pes and impossible with HTML (at least
formally).

 * I am not sure why pro=
tocol method is important. We have the uniform
interface so any method may =
be called on any resource. It might be a
useful hint sometimes but is it ev=
ery required?

 * I don't know of any form-ish vocabularies for RDF, but it=
 doesn't
seem like that would be all that difficult to implement. That bein=
g
said, i don't feel like that not having forms is a show stopper for a
med=
ia type.

 * Idempotency is defined by the uniform interface (at least in H=
TTP),
not by the media type. Why would a media type need to encode this typ=
e
of information?

Maybe i am missing your point?

I don't know if RDF-ish =
approaches are a good way to build RESTful
HTTP systems but they seem like =
they might be. `@rel` really is very
similar to the property id in RDF. Oth=
erwise RDFa would not be able to
use it for that purpose so effortlessly.

=
I suppose RDF does make finding navigable links in a tad more
difficult. Yo=
u have to look at all the properties and find the ones
whose value is a res=
ource, rather than having a separate list of
properties with resources as v=
alues vs properties with other types of
values. OTOH, I have always thought=
 it weird that the REST community
treats links a magically special. Unifyin=
g the model make me more
comfortable: a link is nothing more, or less, than=
 a property of a
resource whose value is another resource.

Peter

> RDFa s=
eems to come the closest to mixing both design goals and it
> starts from t=
he hypermedia design then adds RDF elements. =A0I haven't
> found an invers=
e of the RDFa model.
>
> mca
> http://amundsen.com/blog/
> http://twitter.c=
om@mamund
> http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me
>
>
>
>

12:30, Bob Ferris <zazi@...> wrote:
>> Hi Markus,
>>
>> well, from my =
POV (a Semantic Web biased one), I would agree. However, I
>> always got an=
d get the impression that the REST/hypermedia community
>> doesn't agree on=
 this equation*.
>> I guess, it has something to do with the hypermedia sup=
port that
>> surrounds the utilisation of link relation types, i.e. they ar=
e values
>> of rel attributes of tags, e.g., "link", "a", or "area". These =
tags and
>> their attributes define the processing (e.g. enc-type, method, =
...) of
>> referred resources (in the media type definition). Furthermore, =
in such
>> a hypermedia context a client should know whether it is a naviga=
tional
>> link, an embedded link, etc.
>> On the other side, RDF is a data =
model or knowledge representation
>> structure, which should be embeddable =
into other existing hypermedia
>> media types (as it already can done with =
RDFa, see XHTML+RDFa). So RDF
>> serialisation (/representation) formats do=
esn't need this
>> functionalities themselves.
>> I somehow believe that is=
 better, if these two concerns are separable
>> and one could mix them as n=
eeded, because not every client needs the
>> knowledge of the underlying re=
source/model description.
>>
>> Cheers,
>>
>>
>> Bo
